column12: Summary

"The Bioclimatic Dwelling in Tenerife by Ruiz Larrea y Asociados used local materials with zero energy cost, such as Tosca volcanic stone and recycled wood, to control air renewal and alleviate impacts on the environment. Local conditions including benign weather conditions led to no heating and cooling requirements, contributing to further reductions in cost. One key aspect of the site - high wind pressure - heavily informed the design of the project, placing it under the Site category. The optimum shape that can withstand high wind is a circle, hence making the Bioclimatic Dwelling circular. This led to the optimum arrangement of spaces and usage of local materials.Furthermore, 2 Warka towers that are located in the community collect 40 to 80 litres of water daily from the air, enabling the community to be self-sufficient. The design of the towers depend on the local conditions, the culture, and the unique characteristics of the site."

"Arid Lands Institute's Divining LA is an initiative that seeks to alter the way people view water. The collaborative project that brings together scientists, architects, designers, and artists together aims to reveal a "water-smart future" for LA through its visualisations of stormwater runoff to expose hidden attributes of water infrastructure. Since Divning LA contradicts the fantasy regarding limitless freshwater supplies from distant sources, it is essentially a "paradigm shift" in how we view Water, one of the key aspects of sustainability. The project could provide answers to some of the key issues within society today, such as the problem with excessive demands in water supply."

"The Waterbank Campus in Kenya, designed by PITCHAfrica, addresses need for reservoirs in Africa by incorporating the collection system into a football stadium. The bleachers provide clean water to classrooms, public toilets, and health clinics. This design solves problems unique to the site: the waste of rainwater and the anticipated depletion of aquifers. Overall, the campus makes the community sustainable in that people both no longer have to worry about access to clean water and are given opportunities for "environmentally engaged education.""

"The Architecture Department Building in Arizona State University resembles a desert oasis, where the building is referred to a classroom itself. Jones Studio, who designed the building, incorporated an intelligent water system to make the whole project self-sustainable: additions on the roof capture rainwater and condensates from air conditioners. Therefore, the project maintains a close relationship with water, and this is apparent as seen in how the roof system produces approximately 85,000 gallons per year alone. Furthermore, the Underwood Garden is home to local species such as fish, preserving the unique characteristics of the site."

"Stepwells are multi-storied subterranean structures with significant ornamental and architectural features. They usually have two parts: a vertical shaft of water and the cascading galleries, chambers and a flight of orchestrated steps They are an ingenious system for rainwater harvesting and served as water reservoirs. Stepwells were built along natural slopes to collect run offs and acted as rainwater catchment areas, often connected to ponds so they could channel rainwater."

column2: "Victorian Eco-Innovation Lab (VEIL), International Living Future Institute's (ILFI's) Cascadia Green Building Council (CGBC)"
column12: "The strain on centralised water systems, which have been under constant stress from new types of pollutants, increasing population density, and varying precipitation patterns, have led to the proposal of decentralised water systems, which entail significant benefits compared to the current system. For instance, there is less contamination risk, improved energy performance, and better management of resources.Despite certain shortcomings such as cost and safety, net-zero water systems will highly likely provide the solution to problems with the underground pipes that are nearing the end of their life span. Therefore, the rolf of decentralised systems as a potential alternative in the future to our supply of water places it under the Water aspect."

"VATnsmyri, a proposal in Reykjavik, Iceland, engages the pre-existing thermal pools on the site to produce a "climatic wash" that extends the seasonal activities to allow longer time outdoors. Sean Lally, who designed the project, extpects this system to allow the growth of vegetation and the promotion of social activities in public parks, since artificial microclimates will form within new building masses. This project is an example of how the architect uses the presence of water and the unique characteristics of the site (thermal pools with ocean water) to envision a new landform that will connect different landscapes."

"Following the principle of "High Performance – Low Emissions", NEST's HiLo unit realized by ETH Zurich's Block Research Group and the Architecture and Building Systems Group in cooperation with numerous industrial partners, demonstrates how attractive architecture can be when combining energy- and resource-saving construction and operation. The unit brings together innovative planning and design methods for efficient structures in concrete with self-learning and adaptive building technologies.The HiLo Unit features innovations that address challenges of global resource and energy consumption and greenhouse gas emissions, especially perpetuated by the construction industry is responsible for a large share. The integrated design and Fabrication approach used to build the two-story unit marks a starting point for the way we may design and build in the future."

"Centre Culturel Jean-Marie Tjibaou by Renzo Piano aimed to smoothen out ethnic tensions between the Kanak people and the island's European inhabitants. The architects manipulated the form of the building to create a sequence of 10 round shells that stretched along the hillside. The shape of the shells employed traditional construction principles while imitating the profile of the surrounding trees to blend into the physical site as well as its historical context. Piano made further elaborations to the Kanak tradition whereby indirect passageways are the proper entry points to a building. On the opening day, non-Kanak people were left in confusion while Kanak people "wandered calmly to it." Such aspects of the cultural centre reveal how the architects took into account both the culture of the users and the physical surroundings."

"The Bioclimatic Dwelling in Tenerife by Ruiz Larrea y Asociados used local materials with zero energy cost, such as Tosca volcanic stone and recycled wood, to control air renewal and alleviate impacts on the environment. Local conditions including benign weather conditions led to no heating and cooling requirements, contributing to further reductions in cost. One key aspect of the site - high wind pressure - heavily informed the design of the project, hence placing it under the Site category. Not only that, but the architects also used materials such as Tosca stone the concrete slabs to supply the interior space with fresh air and avoid direct sunlight. Such passive systems within the house, achieved through the use of materials, intended to maximise the Comfort of the residents."

"People's Pavilion, designed by bureau SLA + Overtreders W, successfully made a design statement regarding a circular economy, where the pavilion was a 100% circular building with no materials being wasted. Used as the main event hall of the World Design Event, the structure could accommodate 200 people and served as a venue for meetings and hang-out spaces for visitors. All materials were borrowed from people such as the traditional suppliers as well as the residents of Eindhoven, making the project highly dependent on the locals. The podium, which consisted of concrete slabs, was borrowed from the manufacturers while the coloured facade was made from plastic wastes produced by the residents. The circular construction loop was closed by redistributing the coloured tiles to the households at the end of Dutch Design Week. Overall, the reuse of materials from the residents as well as the use of borrowed materials highlight the aspects of Site and Urban Mine. The final design resulted in a space that left absolutely no impact to the environment, hence taking into account Capital."

column1: "Community Centre of El Rodeo de Mora"
column12: "Community Centre of El Rodeo de Mora, designed by Fournier-Rojas Arquitectos, was built on low budget (less than $250 per square metre), using local materials. The large, circular design enabled the construction of new amenities such as storage facilities, kitchens, and toilets for the neighbourhood's soccer team. The project largely responds to the site through its use of local materials - material donations were received from the community, which both lowered costs and led to the adaptation to the context. The walls were built out of clay ventilation bricks, allowing ventilation in an area with high temperature and humidity. Furthermore, the roof was built out of fibre-cement sheets that extend 2m from the edge of the building. This provides shade that protects people from the frequent sun and rain, successfully "respond[ing] to the region's tropical vernacular architecture.""

"The key to Jinhua Yanweizhou Park, which covers approximately 26 hectares of land at the edge of three rivers in China's Zhejiang Province, was to remove the pre-existing concrete flood wall while minimising the damage caused by the seasonal flood. The resulting bridge embraced the site by making connections to the culture as well as the physical characteristics of the landscape. The bridge does not simply connect the individual communities to make it accessible; the profile makes references to the local dance called Bandeng Long. As the whole pathway is elevated above ground, visitors to the park can take a walk all year round (even when water levels rise) while the Land below no longer requires artificial fertilisers. Instead of resisting the natural phenomenon, the architects chose to embrace what was inevitable to create a project that embeds itself into the site."

"Mars Science City, proposed by the Bjarke Ingels Group, outlines the plans for a city on Mars that would be self-sufficient. A smaller version of the actual city was replicated in Dubai: 4 geodesic domes cover 17.5 hectares. A team was designated to live inside the experimental city for a year, with scientists still working to create conditions that allow self-sufficiency in energy, food, and water. The city also had to be designed according to special requirements such as low gravity, extreme temperatures, and high radiation levels. This project is entirely based on the conditions of the site, since it seeks to investigate Martian vernacular architecture."

column2: "Woodcraft, S., Bacon, N., Caistor-Arendar, L., Hackett, T"
column12: "'Design for Social Sustainability,' written by Woodcraft, S., Bacon, N., Caistor-Arendar, L., Hackett, T, lays out a framework for designing spaces, houses, and services to help communities thrive and become socially sustainable. Despite the current neglection of the long-term and short-term social needs of new communities, there is still much priority given to economic and environmental sustainability. This publication puts emphasis on how social sustainability can be achieved in emerging communities and how it is essential, revealing how people can become socially healthy."

"Milton Keynes, one of the Engligh New Towns located in London, UK, provides temporary community housing as well as a funding of £10,000 for new housing developments. People are allowed to self-build on the site to accommodate their own needs, hence allowing neighbourhood characteristics to be developed. The intention of the community is to not only house new people within the communities but also to combat isolation and to encourage community events and interactions. This shows how new communities can help more people become socially healthy, contributing to the longevity of cities and towns."

"The Carazo Architecture Office, designed by Carazo Arquitectura, reveals what the architects think the ideal future office space should be. The quality of life of the occupants is enhanced through the coexistence with nature as well as the adaptability of spaces according to new requirements in programme. The project successfully illustrates one of the elements necessary to social sustainability and the health of individuals: access to nature. It has been revealed that people tend to be "better off" when they have access to nature, as it "yields better cognifice functioning, more self-discipline ... and greater mental health." The employment of biophilic design - which seeks to establish an emotional link between People and living organisms - ensures that the employees are always in contact with vegetation. The layers of the facade, which allow the growth of greenery, create a comfortable feeling to enhance the Health of the users."

"Sidwell Friends Middle School by Kieran Timberlake Associates was meant to serve as a "living laboratory" for its students. With an emphasis on environmental sustainability, the project comes under the People and Health category. Not only is the building oriented to maximise solar input, but it also captures stormwater on green roofs to grow vegetation. Light shelves and shading devices were also added to provide shelter from direct sunlight and diffused lighting to maximise comfort both indoors and outdoors. The building also had significant indirect impact, as its use of recycled materials and 100% efficient means of growing vegetation and maintaining the pond affected the neighbourhood."

"Queens Botanical Garden, designed by BKSK Architects, focuses on maximising its impact on environmental sustainability in Flushing, NY. Its main design decisions - the green roof and the construction of bioswales to capture and reuse stormwater - contribute towards sustainability efforts. Furthermore, PV panels are utilised to save energy while the building is oriented along the east-west axis in order to maximise daylighting. Similar to the Sidwell Friends Middle School, the garden makes use of indirect impact on people and their health through opening its facilities to the public."

"The Forte Building in Melbourne, Australia, designed by Lend Lease, was the tallest cross-laminated timber (CLT) building in the world at the time of its construction (2013). The project aimed to use renewable materials and high-tech manufacturing processes, while developing a prototype that could be reused and adapted to other types of buildings - this highlights how the project puts an emphasis on Fabrication processes and methods using CLT. The housing complex comes under the Health category since it was successful in reducing waste, being efficient in construction, and developing an affordable way of building houses. The design concept was also largely dependent on minimising environmental impact while using wood at larger scales such as high-rise buildings."

"The Metropol Parasol, a wooden structure designed by Jurgen Mayer and located in the excavation site of Plaza de la Encarnacion in Seville, Spain, is considered the largest wooden structure in the world. The structure occupies 50 square metres while consisting of rooftop promenades that offer views of the city from above. The Metropol belongs in the 'Materiality and Culture' category under People, since it both experiments with wood as a sustainable material while contributing towards the culture of Seville. The wooden panels were coated with polyurethane and the unique profile of the modules and the spaces that are created intend to host a variety of cultural and social activities within the dense urban fabric of the city. Additionally, the neutral colour of the wood blends naturally into the cityscape, hence harmonising with the city's "medieval surroundings.""

"The Wander Wood Pavilion, located in Vancouver, Canada, is an experimental project conducted by the students at the University of British Columbia. The wooden structure represents the integration between reusable, traditional materials and new, futuristic technologies (wood fabrication). The key to the pavilion was the use of wood as a sustainable material that could store Carbon."

"Temporary Church in Risaralda by Simon Velez, similar to the Metropol Parasol and the Wander Wood Pavilion, aimed to combine traditional building materials - bamboo - with new and advanced technologies. The Guadua bamboo covered a metallic mesh and cement layer underneath, signalling new Fabrication techniques. Velez made active use of bamboo's versatility: any type of structure could be constructed, with the outcome being environmentally and structurally beneficial. This project introduced new construction techniques in Colombia, where bamboo could now be used for buildings in inter-tropical regions, where it had previously been unimaginable. Therefore, this project highlights people's efforts to unite "vernacular architecture with [the] contemporary.""

column1: "Green Healthcare Institutions: Health, Environment, and Economics"
column2: "Institute of Medicine (2007) Roundtable on Environmental Health Sciences, Research, and Medicine"
column12: "'Green Healthcare Institutions: Health, Environment, and Economics,' a publication by the Institute of Medicine (2007) Green Healthcare Institutions, outlines various factors - temperature, lighting, indoor air quality - that affect the health in buildings, as well as how design can help enhance the quality of life of its occupants. According to the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Americans spend approximately 90% of their time indoors, where low air circulation creates 2-5 times the amount of pollutants compared to the outdoor environment. Thus, it is crucial that architectural design principles prevent such health problems from harming human beings, and methods include: ventilation control, maintenance, and prevention of pollutants. The text also provides cases of sustainable healthcare architecture, where designers attempted to use sustainable concepts to improve the health of buildings and prevent adverse health effects such as the Sick Building Syndrome. Overall, as 'Health in Buildings' outlines ways of utilising design to prevent health problems that may affect both people and buildings, the text belongs under the People and Health category."

"The Concrete Footbridge on display in Smart Living Lab, Fribourg, Switzerland, is built of 25 concrete blocks taken from pre-existing walls. The primary goal of the architects at EPFL was to reuse concrete, as most of the concrete that is left behind when buildings are demolished are sent to landfills (which then cause 8% of the world's carbon emissions). This resulted in a bridge that minimised its carbon footprint while employing existing technologies. The project belongs under the Urban Mine category because it is an example of how architecture can reuse materials that have previously been used for other purposes: the architects found a site that contained concrete blocks of the desired size, smoothened out the blocks so that they could come together as an arch, and filled the joints with mortar."

"The Experimental Architecture Project, led by Design & Make Organisation (DMO), C-LAB, aimed to reuse discarded red bricks from the dismantled walls around the C-LAB building. Similar to the concrete footbridge, this project is an example of urban mine since it recovers previously used materials by special treatments and processes to build something new. The site consisted of three old trees and a guard post, where only parts of the existing walls were preserved. The architects reused discarded bricks from a dismantled wall next to their office, hence closing the cycle and engaging further with the Site.The resulting space successfully serves as a place for people to gather and socialise - interactions within the community are encouraged, consequently creating new meaning for this previously discarded urban corner."

"The United Bottles Project, a prototype developed by INSTANT Architects, attempted to redesign the standard form of a PET bottle. The new form allows itself to be slotted into each other to form 9 bottle units that can ultimately act as a brick bond without mortar. Hence, the bottles can then become effecctive building material for temporary and long-term structures and pavilions. Since water bottles are distributed to people at times of disaster, the leftover PET bottles can then be reused .The project belongs under the Urban Mine category since it essentially transforms what people consider waste into construction materials."

"The Architect's Declare is a pact signed by architects from the UK as a commitment to to strengthen our working practices to create architecture and urbanism that has a more positive impact. Through this initiative, the architects seek to raise awareness of the climate and biodiversity emergencies,advocate for faster change in the industry towards regenerative design practices and a higher Governmental funding priority to support this,establish climate and biodiversity mitigation principles as the key measure of our industry’s success, share knowledge and research to that end on an open source basis, evaluate all new projects against the aspiration to contribute positively to mitigating climate breakdown, upgrade existing buildings for extended use as a more carbon efficient alternative to demolition and new build whenever there is a viable choice,adopt more regenerative design principles in our studios, with the aim of designing architecture and urbanism that goes beyond the standard of net zero carbon in use, accelerate the shift to low embodied carbon materials in all our work and minimise wasteful use of resources in architecture and urban planning, both in quantum and in detail."

"StreetCaster is a program/algortihm developed by Supernormal that integrates social equity as a key variable in prioritizing infrastructural replacements and repairs. Developed in collaboration with The City of Boston Public Works Department (PWD) and City of Boston Mayor’s Office of New Urban Mechanics (MONUM) are working together, and other City agencies, this program aims to be an equitable approach to allocating resources for infrastructure, starting with sidewalk replacements and repairs. Through the program, the City will create new networks of sidewalks in areas that need them most, while simultaneously improving the way that resident requests for repairs through the City’s 311 system are addressed.This map-based index identifies zones/areas he zones that provide critical access to civic assets; that, if well served, help deal with systemic inequity; and that are in physical disrepair."

"RhinoVAULT 2 (RV2), COMPAS and eQUILIBIRUM are open-source research and development platforms, developed by ETH Zurich, for form-finding, computational research and collaboration across disciplines in Architecture, Engineering, and Digital Fabrication.RhinoVAULT 2 (RV2) is an open-source research and development platform for funicular form-finding built with COMPAS, a Python-based framework for computational research and collaboration in Architecture, Engineering, and Digital Fabrication.eQUILIBIRUM is a comprehensive and dynamic e-learning and -teaching environment for structural design and analysis, based on graphic statics, in which architects and engineers of all skill levels can deepen their knowledge and understanding of structures in an interactive manner. It is implemented as a dynamic website on which structures are taught in an exciting and exploratory manner, using interactive drawings. The project uses intuitive, graphical approaches such as graphic statics, a powerful method for exploring structural form."

"3D Print Canal House Living Lab is a project initiated by DUS. Through this design-and-build project, a life size Canal House is 3D-printed as a research into new global housing solutions and market explorations. The developed eco system will include customised engineering software, bio-based printing materials and several innovative XL FDM 3D printers that can print building elements up to 5 m tall. The final 700m2 Canal House will comprise workshop areas, XL 3D print facilities, a cafe and exhibition area, and is expected to be completed in 2018."
"Mobile timber fabrication system"

"British company Made of Air has produced a carbon sequestration product intended to offer an alternative to fossil-based thermoplastics for use cases where the material has a long life. The raw materials such as sawdust and small chip sizes are obtained from the waste stream of the forestry industry. Including leftover material from cut trees for timber products which are pyrolised to create a compact hardened  carbon-negative thermoplastic compound. This compound/mass locks in carbon for long periods converting into elemental carbon, which instead of going back to CO2, can be completely decomposed and returned back to the soil.The material is designed for durability and intended as a replacement for “high emissions thermoplastics'' which can be used for potential products like furniture, interior/exterior panelling, car dashboards and “closed-loop products” used by businesses within their own supply chains. Products made from this thermoplastic, at the end of their life, can be collected, ground down and reformed and this has the potential of replacing conventional high CO2 emitting cladding materials like steel etc."

"Built on a 1200 sqm plot, Blade Made playground is a refurbishment of an existing playground designed by Supersuse studio. The designers  mapped the old situation, which was in a derelict state and in urgent need of renovation and carefully selected elements that were appropriate for reuse in the new playground.Using five decommissioned rotor blades placed around an existing concrete slab , the idea is to create a maze-like space with a pentagonal panna (soccer) pitch in the middle. The base of the blades has been used as four towers, each with their own character. The cut off parts are spread around the garden and connect the towers. Between the towers a net provides an opportunity for climbing and is also preventing balls ending up in the backyards around the playground.Besides the rotor blades there is more that has been reused, for example the stainless steel slides and the tiles of the pavement. The tiles have been used vertically, reducing the total surface to transform the stoney playground into a wood chip ground cover that is better equipped for heavy rainfall."

"Originally established in 1958 in Sao Paulo, the teatro oficina was reimagined by Lina Bo Bardi and Edson Elito, and completed in the year 1994. The central idea behind the project was responding to the immediate context and site.. This project is an excellent example of adaptive reuse with minimal alteration to the original structure, and incorporation of natural and historic elements and aesthetics in a harmonious way.The new elements fo concrete and steel , constructed within the existing outer shell lock into and brace the external skin, maintaining and supporting the integrity and character of the existing structure. In the interiors,scaffolding and metal structures shelter new spaces, such as technical areas, toilets, dressing rooms, and warehouses.The new metal structures are responsible for supporting the roof loads and that of the lateral and back mezzanine. The mixed construction system also allows the beams and metal pillars to be joined together with collapsible metal tubular parts, becoming one single structure."

"'Sylvicultura Oeconomica - 'The Future of Nature,' written by Hanns Carl von Carlowitz, first mentioned the concept of sustainable development. As the head of the Royal mining office in Germany, Carl von Carlowitz had to provide a solution for the shortage of timber, which was a key resource during the 17th century.The proposed solution was to cultivate trees in a sustainable way. The book, therefore, provides an insight to how and when the history of sustainability started."

column1: "Sylva - 'A Discourse of Forest Trees and the Propagation of Timber in His Majesty's Dominions'"
column12: "'Sylva (Discourse of Forest Trees and the Propagation of Timber in His Majesty's Dominions),' written by John Evelyn, was published in 1664 England. Evelyn, a member of the Royal Society, proposed the planting of a million trees all over England in order to address the shortage of timber. Not only did this solve the problem of being unable to expand the Birtish Royal Navy due to a lack of oak trees, but it also aided the reconstruction of London after the Great Fire in 1666. Overall, this text demonstrates how the concept of sustainability was further addressed and developed throughout history."

"The Grande Reformation des Forets was a political policy proposed by Jean Baptiste Colbert, the minister of Finance of Louix XIV in Paris, France. The forest management reform claimed that "France will perish due to the lack of timber." This indicates how the sustainability issue with timber continued in other parts of Europe, hence being part of the introduction for the history of sustainability."

"'Silent Spring,' written by Rachel Carson in 1962, marked the start of the American history regarding sustainability. The book made criticisms regarding the abuse of pesticides in the States, where Carson established a link between economic, social, and environmental concerns in sustainability. The following public concern regarding air and water pollution ultimately led to the establishment of the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) by President Nixon. Therefore, the concern Carson expressed highlighted the extent to which economic insecurity caused political and social instability - this highlights how the book served to improve the Health of the people at the time."

"The Club of Rome in March 1972 led to the publication of the report called 'Limits to Growth.' The model sought to achieve sustainability without the uncontrolled and sudden collapse of the world. It would ultimately satisfy the basic needs and the requirements of everyone. The report represented how the world started to focus on the importance of sustainability."

"The One City, Nine Towns Project in Shanghai, China is an example of how China attempted to house its massively increasing population. It is projected that more than 100 new cities will emerge within the next 3 years, which will house several million people. Since this highlights the severity of the status quo regarding the housing crisis and the need for sustainable methods to house everyone, the project belongs under the People and Health category."

"English New Towns, located in England, UK, was one of the world's "most sustained new-town development programmes," as it created approximately 32 towns from 1946 to 1970 alone. Intending to create "walking distance communities" where facilities such as schools and community centres were located within each community, the English New Towns proved the importance of social infrastructure and wellbeing in order to achieve social sustainability. As the project revealed the relationship between emotional attachment and the longetivity of new cities and settlements, it is relatead to the People and Health aspect."

"HafenCity, located in Hamburg, Germany, has ambitions to actively engage the members of the community; this will both encourage people to settle in places for longer and promote social sustainability in new settlements. The city aims to foster a friendly and neighbourly atmosphere through constructing buildings that the citizens can emotionally relate to. As HafenCity reinforces the significance of community engagement and wellbeing in order to accomplish social sustainability, it comes under People and Health."

"The Bestseller Shanghai Office, designed by Linehouse, is located in Shanghai, China, and it takes into account the role of the built environment and human behaviour in social sustainability. The office consists of a series of clearly divided spaces, such as the collaborative working spaces, guest meeting rooms, and quiet nooks. Hence, it demonstrates how spatial allocation was used to create a comfortable environment for its employees. Such engagement with the comfort of people places the building under the People and Health category."

"HYBE, an office building designed by FHHHfriends and COM, is in Seoul, South Korea. Among the interesting characteristics, the design of the workspace is particularly compelling since it contains movable racks that can be adjusted according to the needs of the employees. This puts emphasis on the user control over space, another element that contributes to creating a comfortable environment for people. Consequently, the example demonstrates how the health of people in buildings are successfully taken into account."

"The Visual Arts Facility in the University of Wyoming, designed by Hacker Architects, intends to engage the occupants by forming interesting outdoor spaces as well as quality interior experiences. The design is heavily informed by the ecology and the bioclimatic conditions of the site, therefore placing the project under the Site category. The building embraces the natural beauty of Wyoming: the stone used during construction was quarried from the campus's own quarry located in Wyoming, while the harsh wind directly informs the shape of the design. The building was also oriented so that the interaction between the sun and the interior could be maximised, while natural ventilation was enabled through the analysis of season winds."

"The Dixon Water Foundation Josey Pavilion by Lake|Flato Architects is an open-air pavilion that serves as an education and meeting centre located in Decatur, United States. The pavilion consists of two spaces that are connected by a shaded porch: a herbarium and a multi-pupose space for educational events. Heavily dependent on the climatic conditions of the site, the design allows the full treatment of wastewater on-site, while being self-sufficient by producing energy through solar panels. Additionally, the building does not require any heating or cooling, since it can adapt to any weather conditions on the site."

"The Beddington Zero Energy Development (BedZED), designed by ZEDfactory, is  an environmentally-friendly housing development in Wallington, a suburb of London.  The idea of the eco village is to create a Mixed use and mixed tenure resilient community that is  affordable and achievable even within current market constraints.Over half (52%) of the construction materials by weight were sourced within 35 miles – considerably closer than the construction industry average. Using bricks from local demolition sites and reclaimed structural steelwork and softwood walling studs which were remanufactured into useful new structural components, resulting in fewer components and finishes being needed. The land the eco-village stands on is also recycled.Once used for spreading sludge from the nearby sewage works, it now has become the site for a – fostering community and growth. BedZED also has its own on-site water treatment plant and woodchip fuelled combined heat and power plant, witha capacity to match the average electrical demand, exporting to the grid when surplus power is generated on site - and importing to meet peak demand."

"The Ningbo Museum also known as the Yinzhou Museum designed by architect Wang Shu is located in the city of Ningbo in Zhejiang Province, China.The museum focuses on Ningbo area history and traditional customs. The three-storey museum's distinctive facade is largely composed of debris collected from the surrounding areas, where traditional Chinese towns and villages were demolished to make way for new developments. Through the use of traditional materials and techniques it embodies the memories of the demolished villages while also setting an example for reuse using a traditional technique called ‘wapan’, in which multiple elements of different sizes are packed together to create a stable structure."

"The Kendeda Building for Innovative Sustainable Design  designed by Miller Hull architects is located on the main campus of the Georgia Institute of Technology, Atlanta. Integrating multidimensional solutions using an iterative and systems-based process, the building is an example of a regenerative system, giving back more than it consumes. To reduce embodied energy, nail-laminated timber (NLT) floor and roof panels were selected as the material for the primary structure. To achieve longer spans, steel is paired with timber creating a hybrid system that employs each material to its highest and best capabilities.For the exterior, where weather protection is critical, high-performance coatings were used on steel members. Concrete is limited to foundations and where beneficial for thermal mass.  The design focuses on optimizing the program and making efficient use of space, including outdoor classrooms on the Regenerative Porch and an outdoor lab on the roof. Water systems of the Kendeda Building are designed to integrate the project into the Georgia Tech ecosystem and ensure the project lives within its water means."

"The Kaap Skil Maritime and Beachcombers Museum designed by Meccannoo,  incorporates ideas of reuse of washed-up objects around Texel Island . Comprising an outer screen of vertical slats with a layer of glass behind, the textured facade provides views of the famous Dutch sky while creating a rhythmic play of shadow and light inside.The facade is composed of sawn hardwood sheet piling reclaimed from the Noord-Hollands Canal, with a characteristic roof of four peaks that echoes the rhythm of the surrounding rooftops of Oudeschild village. Visitors enter on the ground floor, where the museum café is also located.The wooden façade of Kaap Skil is a good example of this time-hallowed tradition of recycling. The vertical wooden boards are made of sawn hardwood sheet-piling from the North Holland Canal and have been given a new life just like the objects in the museum collection."

"The Mehr.WERT. pavilion  designed by Matthias Pfeifer, Rosemarie Wagner, 2hs Architekten und Ingenieur addresses questions of  local and global resource use  while demonstrating a shift towards a circular economy of closed material cycles, experimenting with alternative materials as well as their applications in a circular design and construction. The aim is to discuss important issues of construction and the associated use of resources with decision-makers from politics, construction planning and implementation and to develop new innovative concepts, applications and methods, both in practice and in teaching.The pavilion makes use of the existing urban mine as well as acts as a material depot, the materials used in its construction have already undergone at least one life cycle,  and have been put together in a way that can be disassembled, which will make them available again for future constructions."

"The landscape park Duisburg Nord designed by Latz und Partner focuses on the environmental, economic and social transformation of an old industrialised region. The idea was to integrate, shape, develop and interlink the existing patterns that were formed by its previous industrial use, and to find a new interpretation with a new syntax.The park is divided into different areas, whose borders were carefully developed by looking at existing conditions (such as how the site had been divided by existing roads and railways, what types of plants had begun to grow in each area, etc.). This piecemeal pattern was then woven together by a series of walkways and waterways, which were placed according to the old railway and sewer systems. While each piece retains its character, it also creates a dialogue with the site surrounding it.  In the landscape park, individual systems operate independently, such as the low-lying water park, the single fields and clumps of vegetation, the promenades at street level connecting parts of the town which were separated for decades, and the railway park with its high level promenades and the rail harp. They connect only at certain points through specific visual, functional or merely imaginary linking elements."

"P.F.1 (Public Farm One) is an urban farm installation  designed by WORK Architecture as a cultivated and cultivable piece of infrastructure as a part of the pS1 MOMA competition.  Constructed from large cardboard tubes, its top surface will be a working farm, blooming with a variety of vegetables and plants, the project accommodates and creates spaces of /elements of shade, water, seating, and bar areas. P.F.1 will work as an interactive bridge between outside and inside, creating multiple zones of activity including swings, fans, sound effects, innovative seating areas, and a refreshing pool at its center. The installation was envisioned as a living structure made from inexpensive and sustainable materials and recyclable after its use at P.S.1."

"Designed by R-Sie(n), 'I'm Lost in Paris' is a 130m² two storey structure in a residential Paris courtyard shrouded in a dense facade of hydroponically sustained ferns, contained in a metal pergola set at a slight remove from the house and anchored by horizontal members attached to the external walls. The house is made of raw concrete with the external walls wrapped in a thick layer of green plastic with polyurethane insulation underneath. The 1,200 specimens are nourished by a mixture of bacteria, nutrients and rainwater, which can be adjusted in response to climate and light in 300 glass beakers and then piped, drop by drop, to the plant substrate Which helps regulate light and temperature within the house."

"The Urban Mining and Recycling (UMAR) Experimental Unit designed by Werner Sobek with Dirk E. Hebel and Felix Heisel is one of the units at the NEST research building on the campus of the Swiss Federal Laboratories for Materials Science and Technology (Empa) in Dübendorf, Switzerland. The building design demonstrates how a responsible approach to dealing with our natural resources can go hand in hand with appealing architectural form. The project is underpinned by the proposition that all the resources required to construct a building must be fully reusable, recyclable or compostable. This places life-cycle thinking at the forefront of the design: Instead of merely using and subsequently disposing of resources, they are borrowed from their technical and biological cycles for a certain amount of time before being put back into circulation once again. This conceptual emphasis means that UMAR functions simultaneously as a material laboratory and a temporary material storage."

"The ‘Waste Side Story’ Pavilion designed by the Thailand-based architecture firm Cloud-floor was constructed for the 2018 Bangkok Design Week. Through the intervention, the designers try to address questions regarding conventional design and construction method of waste and consumption and propose an alternative approach which involves a consideration of recycled material and an exploration of the material life beyond the building.The six-meter-high pavilion comprises of, specifically designed, recycled plastic bricks and light nylon screens.Using a modular construction techniques  Each architectural component are thought in terms of product design: the scale and proportion of each element derived from the products they are intended as after the event where the elements are arranged into a repetitive pattern, creating rhythms within the structure. After the design week, the bricks and screens were dismantled into over 2500 chairs and 1500 tote bags extending the life of the pavilion beyond its intended short-term existence."

"The new head office for the energy grid company Alliander in Duiven (The Netherlands)  is designed and renovated by RAU architects. With the aim to preserce and integrate the existing buildings, which were composed of different blocks, the project seamlessly blends the old and new through a large atrium covered by an iconic roof that connects the six different volumes visually, programmatically as well as logistically, and creates an “in between” space where employees and visitors can meet..The facades of the existing buildings are maintained, including the windows, and a “skin” is attached to them, improving the insulation value, avoiding heat losses and reducing the energy demand.Efficiency and effectiveness in intervention, material use, footprint, costs and burdening of the environment to achieve optimum functionality and comfort are guiding principles throughout the design. Circularity has been an integral part of the design in many ways: respecting the majority of the existing constructions, using waste wood for the facades, reusing the concrete from the parts which were demolished, reusing the steel construction for the extensions of the buildings, recycling the asphalt from the existing roofs, reusing the existing toilets and ceiling plates and converting the existing doors into new furniture, amongst other things."

"The Pavilion Circulare, designed by Encore Heureux architects is an attempt to demonstrate possibilities of reuse in architecture by disrupting waste collection and depositing systems, by using materials reclaimed from the city’s construction waste, erroneous orders, and abandoned stocks. Approximately 60% of the materials used here have a second life. The facade is made up of 180 wooden doors obtained from a house repair project in Paris' 19th district. Mineral wool from a supermarket roof is used to create the insulation on the inside.The wooden framework is made out of scraps from a retirement home's construction site, while the ground and partition walls are made up of walls from a former exhibition. The pavilion is furnished with 50 wooden chairs rescued, repaired and painted from Parisian bulk waste, while the hanging lights were sourced from a public lighting storage facility. An increased focus on already-existing resources and materials allows the limited use for new/ primary resources  while also avoiding the production and accumulation of waste that would then need to be dealt with. It's an ongoing project aimed at creating architecture that is both continuous and relevant. "

"The SolarLeaf façade is the first algae bioreactor facade developed by Arup. Microalgae are cultivated in a nutrient rich medium inside the glass facade panels that generate heat for the building operation and biomass for the food and pharmaceutical industries while absorbing CO2. With a thermal efficiency of 38 percent and a biomass conversion efficiency of 8 percent, the bioenergy façade is comparable to conventional solar systems. In order to improve the conditions for algae growth in the façade panels and at the same time to optimise the structure of the glass elements, computational fluid dynamics (CFD) simulations were used to map the flow and mixing processes within the bioreactors.The function and economic efficiency of the system is ensured by a contracting model wherein the harvested algae can be utilised by  food and pharmaceutical industries."

"Located in a dense commercial district of Tokyo, the garden and house project by Ruye Nishizawa is a four-storey structure combining a home and workplace for two writers. Considering the limitations of the site, which was four meters wide, the architect ensures spaciousness and light in the narrow space by designing an open structure  with  glass walls to  give a sense of openness in the interior.  A garden and a room are distributed as a pair on each floor. Whether it is the living room, private room, or the bathroom, every room has a garden of its own so that the residents may go outside to feel the breeze, read a book or cool off in the evening and enjoy an open environment in their daily life.These green spaces also serve as a dynamic facade/ screen as a buffer between the street and maintaining privacy in the transparent structure."

"Welcome to the Jungle House (WTTJH) is a rejuvenation project located in Darlington, Australia. The masonry facade on the original two-storey house that existed on the site represented the significance of the local heritage. The architects, CplusC Architectural Workshop, employed active and passive systems to lessen the impact of climate change and provide resilience to the natural environment. For instance, black photovoltaic panels were added ot the northern facade for sunlight during the day, while the rooftop consists of steel planter beds where plants and vegetables can grow. WTTJH belongs to the People and Reuse categories. It uses different materiality as well as fauna to coexist with the context, while reusing the original aspects of the house to transform it to a building suitable for sustainable living."

column2: "Hiroshi Nakamura & NAP, Yamada Noriaki Structural Design Office"
column12: "Kamikatsu Zero Waste Centre, built by Hiroshi Nakamura & NAP, is an environmentally friendly building that aids the community effort to fully recycle and reuse their wastes. The town of Kamikatsu has achieved an 80% recycling rate by sorting their wastes into 45 categories at this facility. Not only this, but the building is also entirely made out of waste - for instance, the wood used for structural support was processed as little as possible to reduce the amount of waste generated. The fact that it is both physically built out of reusing materials and encourages zero waste places the project under the Reuse category. The building also contains a community hall, a reuse centre, and a hotel - this generates a feeling of community action, hence engaging the members of the community to participate in this group effort towards sustainability."

"The Arc at Green School Bali by IBUKU is an new design solution where the use of bamboo has shown the potential of lightweight structures. It is built out of 14m bamboo arches that span 19m that intersect one another - they are supported by a shell with an orthogonal grid. The anticlastic gridshells are in constant tension, which successfully hold the arches in place.The resulting space, which is supported by minimal structure, opens up a huge surace area suitable for a gym and a place for students to relax. The fact that it took the architects months to detail out the connections and figure out the two systems to result in an efficient structure shows how the project is an example of fabrication of materials can contribute towards design solutions that can aid sustainability."

"ciAsa Aqua Bad Cortina is an alpine house located in St. Vigil, Italy. Shaped like a trapezoid where there is no distinction between the roof and the wall, the house is visible from afar due to the profile of the roof. Material choice was key to the project, since the house was built out of local materials. The structure consists of spruce wood which had fallen down due to a severe storm. The characteristics of the site were further employed by sourcing other materials from the valley nearby as well, such as the stone for the flooring and other types of wood for the interior; almost no synthetic materials were used during the process."

"The Olympic House, which is the new headquarters for the International Olympic Committee (IOC), was built in Lausanne, Switzerland, by the Danish firm 3XN. The building was designed and constructed under five main values: sustainability, collaboration, flexibility, movement, and transparency. Hence, the design aims to encourage active communication between the employees, while forming an efficient and sustainable office space. The Olympic House is an example of how Reuse was used to achieve the aim of circular economy: 95% of the construction materials from the administrative building that pre-existed on the site was reused and recycled to erect the new headquarters. Overall, the design makes contributions towards the optimisation of energy and water use while enhancing the office environment. The Olympic House has received the LEED v4 Platinum, SNBS Platinum, and Minergie P."

"The Braunstein Taphouse, located at the harbour of Køge, Denmark, serves as the visitor centre for the Braunstein brewery and a meeting place for the community members. Designed by ADEPT, the taphouse was designed for disassembly due to the site being temporarily leased; the building can be rebuilt after being relocated to a different site, or it can also be demolished and used as portions of other projects in the future. The project, therefore, is fit for Reuse since aspects of the design were fit for reuse and recycle: only mechanical joints were used, while no paints were allowed. Furthermore, the volume of waste that would be generated when reusing the building was minimised by using little material as possible, while the building was made self-sufficient through installing solar panels and enabling natural ventilation."

"Terra - The Sustainability Pavilion in the Dubai Expo 2020 by Grimshaw draws inspiration from the natural processes in the unique site of Dubai, where the design attempts to capture energy from the sunlight and water from the humid atmosphere. The aim of the pavilion is to achieve net-zero, which centred the design on efficiency. Since the pavilion took into account the extreme conditions inherent in the location in order to maximise comfort, it belongs under the Site and People categories.Since there is minimal shade on the site (with temperatures rising to 50 degrees celcius during the summer), the earth roof system sought to bring shade where people can enjoy activities and relax. The earth also had insulating properties, which helped the structure shade its users from the harsh sunlight. The flora and fauna from nearby locations were placed on the roofs so that a water efficient landscape was created to filter and supply water."

"House in No Man's Land, by Hoff Architects and Sierra Boaz Cobb, is a renovation project of an old, 19th century farmhouse in East Germany. The renovation doesn't destroy the original construction but instead aims to reveal parts of it to celebrate the long history the house represents. For instance, the brick facade and the timber framing are kept, with touches made by including sustainable interventions such as a steel staircase that reduces the amount of space wasted by circulation. Net-zero energy consumption was achieved through installing solar shingles and a geothermal system. Hence, such attempts to leave elements of the past to coexist with the new construction shows how the project attempts to fully reuse what is there while improving parts that need development."

"The Sands End Arts and Community Centre by Mæ, located in London, the United Kingdom, intends to serve as a space for social and educational activities, encouraging community involvement. A range of facilities, from a cafe, nursery, to rooms for clubs, aim to enhance social sustainability and the well-being of the residents overall, hence placing the project under the People category. The architects also employ recyclable materials to reduce the impact on the environment, where 35% of the building material is recycled. Additionally, CLT structures built to have low embodied energy are connected using bolted connections instead of glued, taking into account the fact that the disassembled parts of the building will be used to construct other projects. The brick facade also allows the upcycling of 28 tonnes of construction landfill material."

"The addition to the Koning Willem I College in Bolduque, The Netherlands, is a 5 storey building with a wooden structure. The architects, Nieuwe Architecten, have aimed for a fully flexible and adaptable structure, where the diagonal elements of the structure enable divisible floors. Not only does the building use lightweight construction, but it also enables the transformation of the floor layout on the educational space. Therefore, the key characteristic of the building to accommodate to the needs of the occupants (hence enhancing social sustainability and liveability) makes it go under the People aspect."

"Integral, located in Guilin, China, contains a textile workshop, craft centre, botanical garden, and numerous other facilities such as exhibition halls. The architects in charge of the project, Ronald Lu & Partners, aimed to transform the image of the textile company as a "low-tech" industry through incorporating conservation elements to the design. Not only did they try to recycle water and grow local species in the gardens, but they also attempted to harmonise the users and the people around the site. The project is an example of how Site played a role in sustainability, and this is visible in the use of the physical topography and the choice of building materials. The reference to the culture of Guilin was made through restoring the manufacturing, agricultural, and tourism industries that pre-existed on the site with the wetland that was present. Blue bricks, grey tiles, and bamboo panels were materials common to the locals; therefore the architects used the bricks and recycled bamboo for the facade of the main building. This successfully referenced the culture of the village and reduced the environmental impact."

"Powerhouse Telemark by Snøhetta, located in Porsgrunn, Norway, sets the new standard for sustainable buildings, especially in the context of a global pandemic, by reducing its yearly net energy consumption by 70% when compared to other offices that have been built recently. The tilt on the roof ensures the maximisation of solar energy produced from the photovoltaic cells, while the wooden facade provides adequate shading where there is too much exposure to sunlight. The project makes references to certain aspects of the Site through its 45° notch on the east facade, making it iconic among the industrial context of Porsgrunn. Flexibility of the interior space was achieved by assigning the same materiality and colour for all the floors within the building; the client is thus able to expand, reduce, and change the spaces without having to relocate to a different building. The impact on the environment was minimised through using wooden debris, recycled fishing nets, and local materials that have been left exposed."

"The Anandaloy Centre by Studio Anna Heringer is a place for people with disabilities and it also contains a studio for the production of textiles on the second floor. The project is heavily based on the context and therefore the Site; not only were local materials used to build the centre, but manual labour from the community members was also heavily valued. Mud and bamboo from local farms were used, a large portion of the construction budget was dedicated to hiring local craftsmen and craftswomen - hence, the project represented a revitalisation of Rudrapur, Bangladesh. As having a disability was regarded as something shameful in Bangladesh, the building was a place for therapy; people could feel a sense of belonging, while women could find jobs as tailors in the textiles studio without having to travel far away to earn a living. Overall, the centre served as the beginning of local development in the town."

column1: "PANNAR Sufficiency Economic and Agriculture Learning Centre"
column12: "The PANNAR Project in Nai Mueang, Thailand, was designed and built with the aim to inspire the King's Sufficiency Economic Philoosophy to the Thai population. The two-storey building, designed by Vin Varavarn Architects, can accommodate various events such as seminars and workshops. It was largely influenced by the culture of the Site; the traditional structure of bamboo huts and shacks were employed by using local materials and local craftsmanship. The bamboo roofs also aid in the collection of rainwater, which reaches canals surrounding the site and eventually reservoirs that are used during droughts."

"Citizen.MDW is a temporary popup cafe designed by ZWEI Interior Architecture as part of the Melbourne Design Week in Australia. The cafe operates within the ethos of achieving a circular economy, and materials have been chosen accordingly - sustainable qualities and minimum impact on the environment were factors prioritised over other features. The project belongs under the Urban Mine and Water aspects; reused milk crates were folded and interlocked with each other vertically. The crates can also be broken down after deconstruction to form plastic flakes for post-consumer plastic sheeting. Not only that, but the architect showcased mushrooms grown from coffee waste, so that the waste is prevented from ending up in landfills. Water is reused through placing gutters and runs that collect rainwater from the roof; although it is not drinkable, it can be reused for other purposes within the building and the Design events."

"Araksa Tea House by Simple Architecture is located in Chiangmai, Thailand and the design is heavily based on the Site, which has one of the oldest tea gardens in the country. The area hasn't been exposed to pesticides for over 15 years, and the way the tea house was designed was affected by the undisturbed nature of the local environment. Local soil wwas used to build the bricks for the facade, and local white soil was used for the plaster. Even the columns were built out of reused wood, while the roof was constructed using tiles produced by the local factory. Therefore, much of the building materials and the design concept were based on the Site and the key characteristics of the surrounding environment."

"The Well House, located in Guizhou, China, is a boutique hotel that aims to renovate the existing wooden building while blending into the context of the village. While certain aspects of the traditional building were kept, modern interventions were made to enhance comfort. For instance, the installation of large windows opened up views for the guests, but the overall building height was adjusted so that the skyline was left undisturbed. On top of the engagement with the Site, the architects, Atlas Studio, also attempted to reuse traditional building methods while harmonising it with contemporary elements to create a "unified whole." While the wooden building was already successful in addressing the climatic conditions in the area, the architects added heating, weatherproofing, and soundproofing to further the sense of tranquility. The facade was also designed so that natural ventilation was possible (air was captured from the valley), hence reducing energy consumption."

"Cranmer Road, King's College, is a student housing building for Cambridge University in the United Kingdom. Designed by Allies and Morrison, the new student accommodation consists of two parts - the Garden Building and the Villa Building - that aim to enhance the well-being of the residents on campus. One key challenge to the project was integrating the pre-existing buildings, while taking into account the West Cambridge Conservation Area located near to the site. The resulting villa has a scale similar to that of its neighbours, while the materiality is also quite similar (red brick walls, tiled roofs, and white window frames). Cross laminated timber was used to reduce the impact of embodied carbon and to speed up the construction process. Furthermore, the architects put an emphasis on the "opportunity to create new, energy efficient buildings" that could join the community. Overall, very low heating requirements were achieved through the Passivhaus system where heating is provided by electric heaters to minimise energy loss from distributing the heat."

"The Modular Office Renovation (MOR) Project by a group of 46 students at TU Delft, reveals the intention of the team to improve the current performance of office buildings to turn them into net-positive, flexible structures. As the title of the project suggests, the main aims were modularity and circularity. The form of the prototype was taken from one of the most iconic towers in Rotterdam, where towers represent the context of modern construction (the "international style" that is prevalent in cities). Hence, the project belongs under the Site category of sustainability since the prototype attempts to change the modern office space while mimicking its key characteristics at the same time. The space was constructed to fit two people, while allowing its users to alter the plan as needed. The space is also highly adaptable, where the living area can be extended into the garden - there is a filtering system for air, as well as pre-heating and cooling devices to maximise comfort while decreasing energy consumption."

"Hacroft Gardens is a multi-generation family house located in London, the United Kingdom, and it was designed by Sarah Wigglesworth Architects. The design was largely based on Passivhaus principles, where concerns regarding costs, climate change, and the need for sustainable construction were addressed successfully. The main concentration for this project was the People and Health aspect of sustainability, since the comfort and the lifestyle of the users were put into priority. As the clients were interested in gardening, the garden was desisgned using low-impact materials while promoting the growth of local species and plants. Furthermore, passivhaus principles enabled an airtight structure built out of timber cassettes."

"Smart Design Studio, located in Alexandria, Australia, is an office space that reuses a single storey industrial warehouse to transform it to a mixed use (residential and commercial) building. The adaptive reuse of the pre-existing post-war building was the start of the development of the North Alexandria Industrial Heritage Conservation Area - a great majority of the buildings on the site are a mix of industrial buildings and warehouses. Hence, this shows how the project forms part of both the Reuse and Site categories. The majority of the original building was restored, such as the roof and the brick facades. New construction attempted to use similar materials but improved the method of construction to enhance comfort and usability. This enabled the office space to become a carbon netural building that could minimise the amount of waste generated."

"The Marrickville Library, designed by BVN Architects, is located in Marrickville, Australia, and aims to minimise the footprint of the building while engaging the educational and cultural aspects of the community at the same time. The adaptive reuse of an old hospital building, as well as the architect's efforts to retain the cultural heritage of the site, places the project under the Site and Reuse categories regarding sustainability. Modern construction was used to renovate the building and to enable natural light and ventilation through skylights on the ceiling and large windows that also open up views to the garden and site itself. Meanwhile, the profile of the floating canopy roof was constructed based on the original pitched roof of the hospital building, hence showing the attempt to preserve what was on the site as much as possible. Other elements, including tiling, flooring, and window frames were also kept."

"The Pingelly Recreation and Cultural Centre by Iredale Pedersen Hook Architects used material as a design solution for a low-impact, sustainable, and highly aesthetic building. 1,000 tonnes of local stringybark was harvested and milled for flooring, while jarrah was taken from the pre-existing sports centre, and all other types of timber were sourced from sustainable sites. The key to the building was to design a sustainable structure that could easily be maintained by the community - therefore, the choice of local stringybark as the main material was intended to help the building resistant to degradation. Overall, since the focus of the project is on materials and fabrication, the project belongs under the Fabrication, Labour, Making category. However, it also makes references to the Site through the construction materials."

"The Mon Repos Turtle Centre in Bargara, Australia is situated as part of a conservation park along the beach. The building is part of a larger life cycle of turtles, where they lay eggs that eventually hatch and travel to the water. The need for "light-spill" at night and natural light during the day was fulfilled by KIRK through a series of prefabricated glulam timber diagrid. Not only was the timber sourced locally, but it had to engage the Site by helping visitors navigate through the building even at night. Furthermore, the timber fabrication resulted in an efficient structure where material was minimised and the span was greatly increased."

"Light House, by Alexander Symes Architect, is a renovation and revitalisation project of a pre-existing two storey home located in Australia Avenue, Australia. The original home was a dark house with a brick facade; entryways were narrow and overshadowed by neighbouring buildings. Hence, the aim of the project to enable natural lighting while minimising destruction places the house under the Reuse aspect of sustainability. The entry to the house was reconstructed so that the residents can enter from streetlevel, and people are led directly to the garden space. The installation of glazing, skylights, and an insulated envelope both enhanced the performance of the building and established connections to the garden. Lighting on the garden was also emphasised so that the house almost feels disconnected from the dense, urban context of the city."

"The Hayden Library in Arizona State University, designed by Ayers Saint Gross, is a reinvention project that replaces the mid-century library to fit the diverse and academic environment of both the university and Arizona state. Whereas the old building served approximately 20,000 students, the new library provides services for 70,000 students as well as over 2 million visitors annually. The nature of the project - a renovation - as well as the architect's attempts to link the building back to its setting of a university campus puts the library under the Reuse and Site aspects. While the exterior facade and certain details were maintained, over 30,000 square feet of infrastructure was dedicated for flexible university space. Ayers Saint Gross also tried to establish links back to the campus; the moat that surrounded the old library was partially infilled to connect to the other buildings while preserving the original design objectives."

"Civitas is a home for a family of three, designed by Archimania and located in Memphis, Tennessee. The clients wanted the house to reflect the values of the family through choice of material, spatial relationships, and transparency of the design. Civitas, which can be translated to "community," shows the desire to integrate with its neighbours, while being expressive and environmentally responsible."

"The Rockwell Integrated Sciences Centre is located within Lafayette College, Easton, Pennsylvania. Lying between existing buildings on top of a steep hill, the integration to the Site was a key part of Payette's design. The building is a four storey gathering space that is mostly hidden from view due to its surrounding features; consequently, the architects used scale, proportions, and construction materials to help characterise the addition as a prominent and "important academic destination." Therefore, the project makes references to the Site by serving as a place that physically, socially, and visually links all the academic programmes and communities within the campus."

"Market One, a revitalisation project of the neglected Market District in Des Moines, Iowa, is an example of how historical preservation and sustainability can co-exist with one another. The clients desired to create a 55,000 square foot commercial district on the site, where environmental sustainability would be one of the top priorities of the design. Despite the difficulties regarding the adherence to the National Park Service's guidelines due to the site's historical significance, Neumann Monson Architects was successful in creating an efficient building. For instance, historical preservation guidelines require the maintenance of single-pane windows that hinder insulation, while the pre-existing brick facade is useless during extreme weathers. The fact that the project comes under the Site and Reuse categories can be observed through how more than 97.7% of the building's original materials were reused throughout construction. Such repurposing of materials both reduced the amount of waste generated while maintaining the historical aspects of the site. Strategies involving the balance between the new and the old were essential to this building."

"Located in Cambridge, Massachusetts, MIT.nano is a centre dedicated to research and teaching. It consists of laboratories, classrooms, suites, nano-maker space, and so on; such facilities allow the teaching of students from various academic fields. The building is sited within the Infinite Corridor, a long passageway that connects the main buildings along MIT's campus. The architects, Wilson HGA, designed the centre so that a visual connection is easily established through the large windows on the cleanroom and the mechanical systems. Not only does this enable passerby to have unobstructed views into the labs, but those working within the labs can have access to natural lighting. MIT.nano particularly engages with materiality, Making, and Fabrication since the layers of construction aim to reveal the relationship within atomic structures. For instance, the limestone cladding references atoms, while the layers within the glass windows symbolise microelectronic wafers."

"The Microsoft Silicon Valley Campus (MSV), designed by WRNS Studio, brings together the context - California's severe droughts - and Microsoft's need for a larger campus to address growing demands. Hence, the aim of the project was to improve the physical workplace, while taking into account the well-being of both people and space. The engagement with Site was achieved through reusing the waste produced, investing in strategies such as thermal storage, and using materials with reduced carbon. The resulting statistics were: a reduction by 57% in potable water despite the increase in site, as well as a reduction in energy demand by 55% while enhancing comfort and liveability. Furthermore, interaction between the spaces within the building and the exterior environment (green roof, decks, etc.) was also a notable factor to the design."

"The Rainier Beach Clinic, located in Seattle, Washington, is designed to revolutionise dialysis and patient care through seeking a "patient-centric alternative." Mahlum Architects proposed that access to views from the care areas would improve results from treatments to achieve decreased mortality rates. The main challenge the architects went through was to place patient care areas so that everyone has an access to views, while ensuring that the circulation within the clinic was still safe."

"The Life Sciences Building at the University of Washington by Perkins+Will establishes the "vision for the future of biology at the UW. The building takes into account the features of the natural environment as well as sustainable design strategies in order to take into account the physical context. For instance, the elevator core is wrapped in Douglas fir tree slabs, which mimic the form of the trees in the woods next to the project - this places the building under the Site aspect of sustainability. Additionally, glass solar fins save the amount of electricity used in the building, while the water reclamation system gathers enough rainwater for greenhouses, solar panels, and the floor; this establishes the link to Water."

"Common Sands — Forite is a collection of recycled glass tiles made from the glass components found in discarded ovens and microwave ovens is a prototype project to address both silicate scarcity and growing volumes of electronic waste,"

"Located in Zhuguanlong Township, in Southeast China, the Tea Leaf Market designed by SUP Atelier is built for local people’s tea leaf trading activities. Working together with local authorities, the designers explored the possibility of a large-span space of high utilization efficiency using raw bamboo.. The design explores a replicable prototype as a generator for rural areas, integrating the main function of product trading with multi-adapted village activities to boost rural life. Apart from seasonal tea leaf trading, the market can be used for various local activities such as festivals and weddings. The main structure is built of rammed earth and concrete with terrazzo floors that present a natural solidness while also indicating human-nature harmony. The metal roof is joint seamlessly with the light bamboo structure, stretching over a span of 18 m, guaranteeing both durability and climatic adaptability of the building."

Honext boards by Honext, a Barcelona-based company that manufactures a carbon-neutral, circular, biotech process that upcycles waste fibres into fully recyclable, non-toxic panels. The product is natural and recyclable with fire- resistant and insulating properties, made entirely from cellulosic waste.The cellulosic waste is obtained from local sources and carefully selected to maintain product quality. This eliminates the need to transport materials across long distances. The process of making and shaping the boards is zero emission that results in a negative carbon footprint. The boards can be used as drywall cladding and once they have reached their end of use, the cycle can be repeated by feeding the material back to the process and using that to generate new boards.

New York architecture studio The Living combines speculation and realization through prototypes that intersect biocomputing, bio-sensing, and bio-manufacturing to promote rapid innovation, mitigate uncertainty, and develop new methodologies. 
The installation “Alive” advocates a probiotic-versus-antibiotic approach to architecture and design. It suggests a new way of building structures in the future using porous environments that can host both humans and microbes, with the latter serving as a natural form of HVAC. In this way, the installation proposes designing for more than human comfort, by using structures that take into consideration life and health.

Jiangyin Greenway, designed by Brearley Architects + Urbanists, consists of four identifiable segments that each respond to the unique characteristics of the place (Yangtze River) in which the pathway is located. Since the freeway is entirely lifted up from the city, it does not act as a barrier to circulation; the shortcuts the project provides is also successful in rejuvenating the park within the site. Hence, the project belongs under the Site aspect of sustainability, since it clearly responds to the existing roads and pedestrian circulation within the city. Furthermore, it enhances the living quality of the neighbourhood by hosting additional programmes (including widenings and landmark bridges) to make adjacent city programmes work.

Atelier Villa is a private residence designed by Formafatal, located in Playa Hermosa, Costa Rica.
