The design intention of the building was to blend in with the surrounding environment, which would clear the clients' minds and allow them to experience luxury at the same time. While the back walls were designed to be windowless to ensure privacy, the priority of the project was to erase the "boundaries between interior and exterior." Such aim places the project underneath the Site category. Additionally, the fact that green roof as well as corten steels were used to achieve the aim references parts of Fabrication as well. The materiality and the colours used for the design scheme succesfully blur the boundaries and give the project a feeling of being warm and natural.

Metro North West is one of the series of eight new stations that were designed and upgraded in Sydney, Australia. The architects, Hassell, devised a round, distinguishable canopy design that was adaptable, efficient, and sustainable for each of the stations. This particular project is noted for the bright "Light Line Social Square" public art - this integrates the climate and social context with the infrastructure.

The Triodos Bank, designed by RAU Architects in collaboration with Ex Interiors, is a fully reconstructible, wooden building that promotes circular construction. Located in Driebergen-Rijsenburg, The Netherlands, the office building is inspired by the natural surroundings as well as the flight paths of bats on the site; the office is also entirely built out of wood and has a minimal CO2 footprint. The reflection of the landscape onto the building's glass facade, as well as the materiality - wood - place the project under the Site and Fabrication categories. The fact that the architects have documented all the products and materials for future use when disassembled takes into account Reuse as well. Screws were used instead of wet joints, which enable the full reuse of all the components within the building.

The aim of Epping Forest House by Studio McLeod, located in Epping, New Hampshire, United States, was to build a "sustainable forever home" on the site of the client's garage. The design reflects the neighbouring houses that have bay windows - the architects made use of a geometric shift where bays were created on the first floor to design an entrance canopy. Materiality was also an important factor in the design scheme, where the bold colour palette of the house was highlighted through enhanced natural lighting. The house was also pre-fabricated in order to quickly assemble and build on site. The larch boards reflect the client's wish to express the Epping forest, located nearby the site of the house.

The Grüne Erde Breathing Headquarters, designed by Terrain: Integral Designs, pursues a plant-based design approach that brings life into the building. The company Grüne Erde works towards the development of products that value ecological and sustainable ways of thinking; just trade and renewable resources are key to the principle of the firm. Therefore, the intentions of the project and the motto of the company were quite similar in that they both combine basic needs with the ecology. The design, overall, introduced a "biophilic breathing" to the building whereby the space was "literally breathing in oxygen."

The Hotel Bauhofstrasse, located in Ludwigsburg, Germany, makes significant contributions to the revitalisation of the surrounding environment while employing wood to convey a special atmosphere within the site. Its location - neighbouring historic buildings within the city - automatically makes it crucial to the Site, while the white Eternit plates initially make the project seem distant and strange. The modules were pre-fabricated in Austria and transported to site for quick assembly and precision. While the white plates trick the viewers into thinking that the building is made from something other than wood, Von M intentionally used locally sourced wood to weigh out the use of concrete within the project to design a CO2 neutral building.

column1: Harvard University Science and Engineering Complex
column12: Harvard University's Science and Engineering Complex (SEC), designed by Behnisch Architekten, aims to inspire learning and display sustainable design methods at the same time. The building contributes towards the development of outdoor space, the revitalisation of streets, and the integration into public spaces that surround the site. Floating above the two-storey plinth (that consists of the public elements of the programme) on the ground floor, the research boxes establish a sense of scale that corresponds to the residential fabric of the campus. The project belongs under the Site aspect of sustainability due to such intertwining of its surroundings. Energy is saved mainly by running outside air through a whole-building air cascade - this allows air to be reused within the building several times before it becomes exhausted.

The Harvey is a six storey residential building designed by CBT, located in Boston, Massachusetts. The building transforms Hood Park, which sits near the site, into a modern, mixed-use development. The addition of the retail space into the design scheme revitalises Rutherford Avenue, hence changing the relationship between the project and the Site.

Swift Factory is part of a community redevelopment project designed by Bruner/Cott Architects, located in North Hartford, Connecticut, USA. It was transformed into a space for the whole community so that people could come for opportunities for jobs, trainings, and youth education. Hence, the revitalisation shows how the factory, previously a site of economic growth, serves as the new centre for social and cultural events. Therefore, the project engages both the Site and Reuse to contribute towards the effort for sustainability. Most of the brick facade was preserved, while minimal changes - the installation of fibreglass windows and the restoration of mortar - were made.
